name: Gautam Kamath 0001
content: Gautam Kamath's Homepage Gautam Kamath Office: DC 1311 Cell Phone: 657-c0mpsci (657-206-7724) Email: g@csail.mit.edu Links to: CV (as of May 2025); Google Scholar; DBLP; arXiv; GitHub; Twitter; Youtube; Blog. My group is The Salon. I host office hours as part of the Learning Theory Alliance. Book a slot here. Feel free to send me comments anonymously here. Note that, by design, I won't be able to respond -- if you need me to, it's better handled via email, or leaving some way for me to reply. About Me I am an Assistant Professor at the University of Waterloo's Cheriton School of Computer Science, a Faculty Member at the Vector Institute, and a Canada CIFAR AI Chair. I run The Salon. I'm interested in reliable and trustworthy statistics and machine learning, including considerations such as data privacy and robustness. I will be moving to the Computer Science department at the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences at NYU in September 2026, and am searching for members to join my group there. More details are available here, and a form to indicate interest is available here. I was a Microsoft Research Fellow at the Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing for the Fall 2018 semester program on Foundations of Data Science and the Spring 2019 semester program on Data Privacy: Foundations and Applications. Before that, I completed my Ph.D. at MIT, affiliated with the Theory of Computing group in CSAIL. I was very fortunate to be advised by Costis Daskalakis. Before MIT, I spent four wonderful years at Cornell University, graduating in May 2012 with a degree in Computer Science and Electrical and Computer Engineering. At Cornell, I was incredibly lucky to have the opportunity to work with Bobby Kleinberg. News (11/22/25) I am now a member of the executive committee of the Symposium on Foundations of Responsible Computing. (11/7/25) Demystifying Foreground-Background Memorization in Diffusion Models accepted to AAAI 2026. (10/9/25) I will be attending a joint NYU and Oxford workshop on mathematical foundations of AI, in January in London. (10/8/25) I am giving a talk at ETHZ's AI center on October 17, and speaking at Daegu Global Robot Business Forum on October 22. (9/18/25) Two papers (1, 2) accepted to NeurIPS 2025. (9/9/25) New paper on arXiv: Not All Samples Are Equal: Quantifying Instance-level Difficulty in Targeted Data Poisoning. (8/28/25) I am teaching CS 480: Introduction to Machine Learning in Fall 2025. Stay tuned for the website. (8/28/25) I will be a jury member on Youssef Allouah's PhD thesis committee. (8/18/25) New paper on arXiv: Demystifying Foreground-Background Memorization in Diffusion Models. (8/16/25) The Broader Landscape of Robustness in Algorithmic Statistics to appear in IEEE BITS magazine. (8/6/25) I will be a senior program committee member for ALT 2026. (7/31/25) I will be giving a talk at The 7th Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning Workshop 2025 at CRYPTO 2025. (7/30/25) I will be on the external review committee for Reed College's Computer Science department. (7/29/25) I will be a reader of Junhao Lin's Master's thesis. (7/22/25) I am now a member of the ICML board, for a three year term. (7/8/25) I organized the 3rd Vector Institute ML Privacy and Security workshop. I gave a talk on machine unlearning. (6/30/25) I will be on the program committee of SaTML 2026. (6/12/25) I will be a co-chair of social media and publicity for AAAI 2026. (5/14/25) Mentee Valentio Iverson wins the Germain-Erdős Undergraduate Award in Mathematical Research. (5/3/25) Optimal Differentially Private Sampling of Unbounded Gaussians accepted to COLT 2025. (5/1/25) On the Learnability of Distribution Classes with Adaptive Adversaries accepted to ICML 2025. (4/29/25) I am a recipient of the Ontario Early Researcher Award. (4/9/25) I am joining the editorial board of the Journal of Privacy and Confidentiality. (3/3/25) New paper on arXiv: Optimal Differentially Private Sampling of Unbounded Gaussians. (2/28/25) I will be on the program committee for SODA 2026. (2/5/25) Quoted in a Toronto Star article about data privacy. (1/22/25) One paper accepted to ICLR 2025. (1/21/25) I will be speaking at Symposium on Mathematical Foundations of Trustworthy Machine Learning in Ascona, Switzerland in October 2025. (1/21/25) I will be participating in an ACL Mentorship Panel. (1/14/25) I was quoted in a news article about NeurIPS high school projects. (1/2/25) Undergraduate advisee Chris Trevisan wins the 2025 CRA Outstanding Undergraduate Researcher Award. (1/1/25) Unbiased Statistical Estimation and Valid Confidence Intervals Under Differential Privacy published in Statistica Sinica. Older News Research Most authorships are in alphabetical order, as is common in areas of computer science. Papers with contribution-order authorship are indicated, and equal contributions are marked with * or ^. Generally, these will put the students as first-author, with equal contribution amongst the senior authors. ⓡ is used for randomized author order.
